quizDescription: Test your knowledge of Black History!
quizTags: Black History, Civil Rights, African American, Equality

questions.question: Who is known as the 'Father of Black History'?
questions.explanation: Carter G. Woodson is known as the 'Father of Black History' for his contributions to the study and celebration of Black history.

questions.question: Who was the first African American to serve as President of the United States?
questions.explanation: Barack Obama was the first African American to serve as President of the United States, serving two terms from 2009 to 2017.

questions.question: Which landmark Supreme Court case ended racial segregation in public schools?
questions.explanation: Brown v. Board of Education (1954) ended racial segregation in public schools, declaring the 'separate but equal' doctrine unconstitutional.

questions.question: Who is considered the 'Mother of the Civil Rights Movement'?
questions.explanation: Rosa Parks is considered the 'Mother of the Civil Rights Movement' for her pivotal role in the Montgomery Bus Boycott.

questions.question: Who was the leader of the Nation of Islam and a prominent civil rights activist?
questions.explanation: Malcolm X was a leader of the Nation of Islam and a prominent civil rights activist known for his advocacy for Black empowerment.

questions.question: Who was the first African American Supreme Court Justice?
questions.explanation: Thurgood Marshall was the first African American Supreme Court Justice, serving from 1967 to 1991.

questions.question: Which African American woman is known for her activism in the anti-lynching movement and women's suffrage?
questions.explanation: Ida B. Wells was an African American woman known for her activism in the anti-lynching movement and women's suffrage.

questions.question: Who was the African American scientist and inventor known for his contributions to agricultural science?
questions.explanation: George Washington Carver was an African American scientist and inventor known for his work in agricultural science, particularly with peanuts and sweet potatoes.

questions.question: Which African American poet and civil rights activist won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993?
questions.explanation: Toni Morrison was an African American poet and civil rights activist who won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993 for her novels exploring the Black experience.

questions.question: Who was the African American baseball player who broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball?
questions.explanation: Jackie Robinson was the African American baseball player who broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball, playing for the Brooklyn Dodgers.

questions.question: Which African American artist is known for her powerful and symbolic paintings depicting Black experiences?
questions.explanation: Faith Ringgold is an African American artist known for her powerful and symbolic paintings, quilts, and story quilts depicting Black experiences.

questions.question: Who was the African American abolitionist and women's rights activist who delivered the famous speech 'Ain't I a Woman?'
questions.explanation: Sojourner Truth was an African American abolitionist and women's rights activist who delivered the famous speech 'Ain't I a Woman?' at a women's rights convention in 1851.

questions.question: Which African American mathematician and NASA employee played a crucial role in the early years of the U.S. space program?
questions.explanation: Katherine Johnson was an African American mathematician and NASA employee who played a crucial role in the early years of the U.S. space program, calculating trajectories for space missions.

questions.question: Who was the African American leader and spokesperson for the Nation of Islam known for his powerful speeches?
questions.explanation: Malcolm X was an African American leader and spokesperson for the Nation of Islam known for his powerful speeches advocating for Black empowerment and self-defense.

questions.question: Who was the African American poet and playwright who became a central figure of the Harlem Renaissance?
questions.explanation: Langston Hughes was an African American poet and playwright who became a central figure of the Harlem Renaissance, a cultural and artistic movement in the 1920s and 1930s.
